title: A Stunning Defeat Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: Metal Wayside sign with paintings of Loyalists falling on a field.
images.title: "A Stunning Defeat" Wayside Exhibit
images.caption: Stunning Defeat Wayside Exhibit

bodyText: It was here, once the Loyalists were in range, that the Patriots opened fire. Patriot cannons and muskets killed at least 30 men, among them was Lieutenant Colonel Donald McLeod. Another 20 or so men were left wounded here on the battlefield. Although some accounts say the battle only lasted 3 minutes, most other accounts suggest the battle lasted around 30 minutes.
audioDescription: A metal wayside exhibit along a dirt path. Down the hill from earthworks.

title: A Trap is Set Wayside

images.altText: Metal Wayside on a dirt path in the forest
images.title: A Trap is Set Wayside
images.caption: Wayside Exhibit

bodyText: Near this spot, on Feb. 26, 1776, Patriot forces set up a defensive position. Late that afternoon, a Loyalist courier arrived to deliver a letter to Patriot commander, Col. Richard Caswell to surrender his troops. While Caswell read the letter and consulted with his officers, the courier surveyed the situation. He observed the Patriot forces with their backs to the bridge. Caswell refused the ultimatum by the Loyalists. The Loyalist courier reported back to the Loyalist Commander, General Donald MacDonald, the observations he made in the Patriot camp.
audioDescription: Metal wayside on a dirt path with trees and Moores Creek behind. Path is flat with a couple of Uneven Surfaces.

title: Grady (Patriot) Monument

images.altText: Stone Monument surrounded by black fence
images.title: Grady Monument
images.caption: Grady Monument

bodyText:
The Patriot Army on February 27, 1776, consisted of men from places like Wilmington, New Bern, and Kinston. They were farmers, merchants, blacksmiths, and slaves. Many of these men still considered themselves good British subjects, but they had grown weary of over-taxation by the British Government.

When the Patriots learned a British Army was preparing to retake the colony by force, many of them who were Minutemen rushed out of their homes and businesses to take up arms against the Crown. Over the course of a few minutes on February 27, 1776, the fate of North Carolina, and the rest of the colonies, was decided here on these grounds. A Patriot victory here would encourage the Sons of Liberty in North Carolina, on April 12, 1776, to vote for Independence. North Carolina was the first American Colony to do so. Like a piece of a puzzle, the Battle of Moores Creek played an ever-important role in completing the quest for Independence from Great Britain.

In 1857, this monument, known as the Grady Monument, or Patriot Monument, was placed here so we could remember the Patriots who fought for our Independence. This monument commemorates this Patriot victory and honors the only Patriot who died during the battle, Private John Grady of Duplin County. During the dedication ceremony in 1857, the cornerstone for the obelisk was laid into a brick foundation, which contained the reinterred remains of Grady.

Sometime during that year, the obelisk, which was imported from Philadelphia, was placed on top of the cornerstone and brick foundation. Staring up at this prominent memorial anchoring the corner of this hallowed ground, let us recall the final thoughts from an “Address Delivered at the Celebration of the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge, February 27th, 1857”:

“So let that monument which on this spot we build, proclaim to all the world the prompt obedience which our brave forefathers yielded to their country’s bidding and show how– “When their country called, and called in wild despair, the Patriots came, and all their soul was here.” Let us my countrymen, ever hallow in our hearts, the spot on which we stand – let the monument we build on it be an altar of freedom where we may ever rekindle the expiring fires of patriotism."

title: Loyalist Monument

images.altText: Granite Monument surrounde by trees alongside a black path.
images.title: Loyalist Monument
images.caption: Loyalist Monument at Moores Creek

bodyText: The Loyalist Monument was placed here in 1909. This granite monument not only honors the Loyalists who fought here, but it also represents choice. Choice is one of our most cherished freedoms. The Loyalists were colonists that chose to remain loyal to Great Britain. Without their choice of loyalty, we would have never had the battle of Moores Creek Bridge, and the first Patriot victory of the American Revolution.
audioDescription: A granite monument surrounded by trees. The path to get to the monument is made of recycled tires and is flat.

title: Moores Creek

images.altText: Dark creek waters with a wooden boardwalk going across.
images.title: Moores Creek
images.caption: Moores Creek with boardwalk

bodyText: Moores Creek made a natural barrier between the Patriots and the Loyalists. Moores Creek is ten feet deep in most places. The deep waters of the creek would force the Loyalists to use Moores Crek to cross, making the bridge an ideal defensive position for the Patriots.
audioDescription: A dark water creek spanned by a wooden boardwalk on one side and a wooden bridge on the other. The boardwalk is relatively flat going across the creek.

title: Moores Creek Bridge

images.altText: Wooden Bridge over creek surrounded by trees.
images.title: Moores Creek Bridge
images.caption: Moores Creek Bridge

bodyText:
Looking across the swamp of Moores Creek Bridge, locally referred to in 1776 as Widow Moores’ Bridge. While we may never know exactly what it looked like, some 18th-century documents, like the 1764 law quoted at left, help shed light on bridge construction. Back then most bridges were built on cypress or heart of pine. Builders were required to construct “good and lawful” bridges “passable for carts and wagons.”

From historical accounts, we know a bridge has sat at this location since 1743. It crossed Moores Creek, connecting Mt. Misery near Wilmington to Cross Creek (now Fayetteville). 
 

As you continue along the trail, you will cross the bridge, tracing the footsteps of Patriots and Loyalists.


A Bridge Through Time
The appearance of Moores Creek Bridge has changed over time. Colonial wood bridges lasted about 10 years; Moores Creek Bridge may have been replaced as many as 10 times between 1743 and 1851.
audioDescription: A wooden bridge surrounded on two sides by water and a swamp.

title: Mother Covington and her Daughter

images.altText: Large cannon in foreground with small swivel gun behind dirt mounds
images.title: Mother Covington and her Daughter
images.caption: Mother Covington and her Daughter

bodyText:
Here behind strong earthworks, the Patriots set up a deadly ambush. Cannons and muskets are placed on a high sloping ridge above Moores Creek Bridge. The oncoming Loyalists never had a chance.

Today you see a historic reproduction of two cannons, a larger one, Mother Covington, and a smaller swivel gun, Mother Covington's Daughter. They sit today behind the strong Patriot earthworks.
audioDescription: Grassy area with dirt hills and two cannons behind the hills along a flat asphalt path.

title: Patriot's Hall

images.altText: One-story building painted light brown with dirt path in the front. Wooden sign in foreground.
images.title: Patriot's Hall
images.caption: Patriot's Hall

bodyText: Patriot's Hall is a community building located within the park. Maintained by the NPS, Patriot's Hall is home to park events such as Naturalization Ceremonies and parts of the park's anniversary program. The building can be rented through the special use permit process. Please contact Superintendent Matthew Woods (matthew_woods@nps.gov) for more information.

title: Road to Independence
listingDescription: Wayside Exhibit focused on the leadup to the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge.

images.altText: Wayside Exhibit just off a rubber trail looking down on a grassy field with trees
images.title: Road to Independence Wayside
images.caption: Road to Independence Wayside

bodyText:
As you take a step back in time to 1776, you will find that political and social tensions in North Carolina were at an all time high. While Patriot leaders worked to ease tensions with Great Britain, they also made enemies within their own colony. Loyalists were those colonists who remained loyal to Great Britain. Many of these were new immigrants from the Highlands of Scotland.

This trail is only one mile along a paved walkway and boardwalk. The landscapes you will see may appear like many others – a winding country road, a narrow bridge across a creek, a swampy tidal wetland. But something here is different. Christened by combat, commemorated by proud descendants, this place is now a national treasure. Follow this path and you will discover why.
audioDescription: Wayside Exhibit with drawings of soldiers, just off a rubber trail looking down over a grassy field with longleaf pine trees. There are also several tree stumps.

title: Road to the Sea Wayside

images.altText: Wayside Exhibit containing a map of North Carolina with Patriot and Loyalist troop movements.
images.title: Road to the Sea
images.caption: Road to the Sea Wayside

bodyText: This wayside exhibit shows the troop movements by both Loyalist and Patriot soldiers on their march to Moores Creek Bridge. Take a look at the map on the wayside. You can see where the Loyalists had crossed the Black River at Corbett’s Ferry, above the Patriot position, and almost captured the Patriots just north of Moores Creek. Richard Caswell, the Patriot Commander, ordered his men to fall back to Moores Creek Bridge, a crossing the Loyalists would have to make.
audioDescription: This wayside exhibit is located at the intersection of the paved trail and a dirt trail. You will be walking through a heavily forested area with a grassy savannah to your left.

title: Stage Road Monument

images.altText: Small Stone Monument (about four feet high) with grassy field around it.
images.title: Stage Road Monument
images.caption: Stage Road Monument

bodyText: The earthworks on the east side of Moores Creek, were designed in a circular pattern. This design served to help the Patriots protect their position from all sides. During the time of the battle, it is believed that the walls of the earthworks were around five feet tall.
audioDescription: You are now standing on a dirt surface at the entrance to the battlefield. On either side of you are dirt earthworks.

title: Venus Fly Trap Planter

images.title: Venus Fly Trap Planter
images.caption: Venus Fly Trap at Moores Creek

bodyText:
The Venus Fly Trap looks like any other plant, but it contains a deadly secret. It is one of the only carnivorous plants in the world. How does such a simple plant lure unsuspecting animals?

The plant gives off a smell that attracts potential prey (namely insects, spiders, and beetles. The animals fly into the open trap and start pressing against the exposed hairs. Once the hairs have been triggered twice, the trap slowly starts to close on the unsuspecting animal. After a few days of digestion, the plant reopens, ready for its next meal.

Humans continue to be fascinated with this plant and as a result the plant is on the endangered species list. Moores Creek National Battlefield is one of the only places you will find these wonders of nature in the wild.
audioDescription: The Venus Fly Trap planter is a circular brick design about 2 feet off the ground. Inside the planter contains the rare Venus fly trap.

title: Very Bad Swamp Wayside Exhibit

images.altText: Wooden Boardwalk going across a dark creek
images.title: Very Bad Swamp Wayside Exhibit
images.caption: Wooden Boardwalk across Moores Creek

bodyText: Moores Creek made a natural barrier between the Patriots and the Loyalists. Moores Creek is ten feet deep in most places. The deep waters of the creek would force the Loyalists to use Moores Crek to cross, making the bridge an ideal defensive position for the Patriots
audioDescription: A dark water creek spanned by a wooden boardwalk on one side and a wooden bridge on the other. The boardwalk is relatively flat going across the creek.
